skill.name: Git Workflow Skill
skill.description: Git workflow management including branch validation, commit conventions, PR preparation, and repository health checks.
skill.summary: Git workflow management including branch validation, commit conventions, PR preparation, and reposit...
skill.author: ByronWilliamsCPA

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based documentation skill with no code execution capabilities. It only provides Git workflow guidance, branch naming conventions, and commit message templates.

content.value_statement: This skill helps developers follow consistent Git workflows with standardized branch naming, commit message conventions, and pull request preparation. It ensures repository health and team collaboration through automation-friendly practices.
actual_capabilities: Validate branch naming conventions (feat/, fix/, docs/, etc.)
Prepare conventional commit messages with semantic structure
Generate pull request descriptions from commit history
Check repository status and health indicators
Map branch prefixes to semantic versioning impacts
Enforce consistent git workflow patterns across teams
limitations: Does not execute git commands directly
Requires user to run git commands manually
Does not resolve merge conflicts automatically

use_cases.title: Follow commit standards
use_cases.description: Create properly formatted commits that work with semantic release automation

use_cases.title: Enforce branch policies
use_cases.description: Validate team members use consistent naming and workflow patterns

use_cases.title: Streamline PR reviews
use_cases.description: Generate comprehensive PR descriptions automatically from commit history

prompt_templates.title: Check branch status
prompt_templates.scenario: Review current branch and repository state
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me the current git branch and repository status

prompt_templates.title: Create feature branch
prompt_templates.scenario: Start work on a new feature
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a new feature branch following our naming conventions for implementing user authentication

prompt_templates.title: Write conventional commit
prompt_templates.scenario: Commit staged changes with proper format
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me write a conventional commit message for adding user login functionality

prompt_templates.title: Prepare pull request
prompt_templates.prompt: Prepare a pull request description for my feature branch based on the recent commit messages

output_examples.input: Help me create a conventional commit for fixing the login bug
output: âœ“ Suggested commit format: fix(auth): resolve login validation error on empty password field
âœ“ Ready to commit with: git commit -m "fix(auth): resolve login validation error on empty password field"

best_practices: Always validate branch names before creating commits to ensure semantic versioning works correctly
Use conventional commit format so automated tools can determine version bumps and generate changelogs
Prepare PR descriptions early by reviewing commits throughout development rather than at the end
anti_patterns: Using generic branch names like 'test-branch' or 'wip' instead of typed prefixes
Writing commit messages without type prefixes that automated release tools can parse
Skipping PR checklists and creating pull requests without context for reviewers

faq.question: Does this skill execute git commands?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides guidance and templates. You must run git commands manually in your terminal.

faq.question: What branch types are supported?
faq.answer: feat, fix, docs, refactor, perf, test, chore, and hotfix. Each maps to specific commit types and version impacts.

faq.question: How do I integrate with semantic release?
faq.answer: Use the conventional commit format. feat commits trigger minor versions, fix commits trigger patch versions.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only reads your git repository state. It does not modify files or send data externally.

faq.question: Why is my branch name rejected?
faq.answer: Branches must follow the pattern {type}/{description}. Use only approved prefixes like feat/, fix/, or docs/.

faq.question: How is this different from git CLI?
faq.answer: The CLI executes commands. This skill provides workflow guidance, validates conventions, and generates templates.
